justification: Lupus erythematosus commonly presents with a malar rash (dyspigmentation), arthritis (arthropathy), fever, and can sometimes present with follicular hyperkeratosis and atrophic scarring.}, {diagnosis: Dermatomyositis

justification: Dermatomyositis, like lupus, features the overlap of skin findings and musculoskeletal symptoms.  Dyspigmentation, particularly Gottrons papules, is a hallmark.  Arthritis, fever, and follicular hyperkeratosis can occur.}, {diagnosis: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)

justification: MCTD shares features with lupus and other connective tissue diseases.  It can manifest with similar skin changes, joint involvement, and systemic symptoms like fever.}, {diagnosis: Sjögrens syndrome
justification: Though primarily known for dry eyes and mouth, Sjögrens can have systemic manifestations.  Skin changes, joint pain, and fever are possible.}, {diagnosis: Adult-onset Stills disease

justification: This inflammatory disorder often presents with fever, a salmon-colored rash (dyspigmentation), and arthritis.  While less common, skin changes like hyperkeratosis can occur.}, {diagnosis: Reactive arthritis
justification: Often triggered by infection, reactive arthritis can cause joint pain, skin rashes, and fever.  The skin involvement is variable.}, {diagnosis: Drug-induced conditions

justification: Many medications can cause a wide range of side effects, including skin reactions (dyspigmentation, hyperkeratosis), joint pain, and fever. Its crucial to review medication history.}, {diagnosis: Infections (viral, bacterial, others)
justification: Infections can cause a constellation of symptoms, often including fever.  Skin rashes and joint pains can accompany various infections.}, {diagnosis: Sarcoidosis

justification: Sarcoidosis, a multisystem granulomatous disorder, can affect the lungs, skin (erythema nodosum), and joints.  Fever and less common skin changes are possible.}, {diagnosis: Paraneoplastic syndromes
justification: In rare instances, certain cancers can trigger immune responses that manifest with skin changes, arthritis, and systemic symptoms.}
